    • Using a custom dictionary"

Using a custom dictionary“

Emily Kothe

2018-12-13

Source: vignettes/custom_dictionary.Rmd
custom_dictionary.Rmd

This gendercodeR package allows rapid recoding of freetext gender responses using an in-built dictionary. Individuals using the package may wish to extend or overwrite elements of the dictionary where they disagree with the coding decisions made by the package authors and/or wish to include recoding options that are not included in the in-built dictionary. A custom dictionary can be created by the user and provided to the genderRecode() function for this purpose.

Adding new items to the dictionary

For example, when collecting data from Spanish speaking participants a participant who enters their gender as “masculino” will not be recoded using the in-built dictionary.


df <- data.frame(stringsAsFactors=FALSE,
      gender = c("male", "MALE", "mle", "mail", "masculino", "female", "enby"),
         age = c(34L, 37L, 77L, 52L, 68L, 67L, 83L)
)

df
#>      gender age
#> 1      male  34
#> 2      MALE  37
#> 3       mle  77
#> 4      mail  52
#> 5 masculino  68
#> 6    female  67
#> 7      enby  83

library(gendercodeR)
#> Welcome to the genderCodeR package
#> 
#> This package attempts to remove typos from free text gender data
#> The defaults that we used are specific to our context and your data may be
#> different. We offer two categorisations -- 'broad' and 'narrow.' Both are opinionated
#> about how gender descriptors collapse into categories as these are culturally
#> specific they may not be suitable for your data. In particular, the 'narrow'
#> setting makes opinionated choices about some responses that we want to
#> acknowledge as potentially problematic.
#>       In particular,
#>         * In 'narrow' coding, intersex responses are recoded as 'sex and gender
#>           diverse'
#>         * In 'narrow' responses, where people indicate they are trans and
#>           indicate their identified gender are recoded as the identified gender
#>           (e.g. 'Male to Female' is recoded as Female). We wish to acknowledge
#>           that this may not reflect how some individuals would classify
#>           themselves when given these categories and in some contexts may make
#>           systematic errors. The broad coding dictionary attempts to avoid these
#>           issues as much as possible - however users can provide a custom
#>           dictionary to add to or overwrite our coding decisions if they feel
#>           this is more appropriate. We welcome people to update the inbuilt
#>           dictionary where desired responses are missing.
#>         * The 'broad' coding separates out those who identify as trans
#>           female/male or cis female/male into separate categories it should not
#>           be assumed that all people who describe as male/female are cis, if you
#>           are assessing trans status we recommend a two part question see:
#> 
#>           Bauer, Greta & Braimoh, Jessica & Scheim, Ayden & Dharma, Christoffer.
#>           (2017).
#>           Transgender-inclusive measures of sex/gender for population surveys:
#>           Mixed-methods evaluation and recommendations.
#>           PLoS ONE. 12.

genderRecode(df)
#> 
#> The following responses were not auto-recoded. The raw responses
#>         have been carried over to the recoded column 
#>  
#> # A tibble: 1 x 2
#> # Groups:   responses [1]
#>   responses     n
#>   <fct>     <int>
#> 1 masculino     1
#>      gender age gender_recode
#> 1      male  34          male
#> 2      MALE  37          male
#> 3       mle  77          male
#> 4      mail  52          male
#> 5 masculino  68     masculino
#> 6    female  67        female
#> 7      enby  83    non-binary

The custom dictionary should be a data frame with two columns. Column 1 should include the input text (i.e. the response provided by the participant) and Column 2 should include the desired output text (i.e. the gender category the input should be converted to).


custom_dictionary <- data.frame(stringsAsFactors=FALSE,
       Input = c("masculino", "femenina"),
      Output = c("male", "female")
)

custom_dictionary
#>       Input Output
#> 1 masculino   male
#> 2  femenina female

The custom dictionary is appended to the in-built dictionary and participants are recoded as desired.

genderRecode(df, customDictionary = custom_dictionary)
#>      gender age gender_recode
#> 1      male  34          male
#> 2      MALE  37          male
#> 3       mle  77          male
#> 4      mail  52          male
#> 5 masculino  68          male
#> 6    female  67        female
#> 7      enby  83    non-binary

Overwriting existing entries in the dictionary

The narrow recoding method recodes participants who indicate that they are intersex are recoded to “Sex and Gender Diverse”. In some contexts researchers may wish to use narrow recoding but overwrite this particular behaviour so that individuals who report they are coded as intersex but the other entries in the dictionary are preserved.1


df <- data.frame(stringsAsFactors=FALSE,
      gender = c("male", "MALE", "mle", "mail", "intersex", "female", "enby"),
         age = c(34L, 37L, 77L, 52L, 68L, 67L, 83L)
)

df
#>     gender age
#> 1     male  34
#> 2     MALE  37
#> 3      mle  77
#> 4     mail  52
#> 5 intersex  68
#> 6   female  67
#> 7     enby  83

genderRecode(df, method = "narrow")
#>     gender age          gender_recode
#> 1     male  34                   male
#> 2     MALE  37                   male
#> 3      mle  77                   male
#> 4     mail  52                   male
#> 5 intersex  68 sex and gender diverse
#> 6   female  67                 female
#> 7     enby  83 sex and gender diverse

A custom defintion can be provided and then be applied.


custom_dictionary <- data.frame(stringsAsFactors=FALSE,
       Input = c("intersex"),
      Output = c("intersex")
)

genderRecode(df, method = "narrow", customDictionary = custom_dictionary)
#>     gender age          gender_recode
#> 1     male  34                   male
#> 2     MALE  37                   male
#> 3      mle  77                   male
#> 4     mail  52                   male
#> 5 intersex  68               intersex
#> 6   female  67                 female
#> 7     enby  83 sex and gender diverse

  1. The package authors wish to acknowledge that the narrow categories make opionated assumptions and that the broad recoding will generally be more appropriate.↩
